title: Electric current - charge graph from current graph

content.question: The graph shows the current as a function of time at a point along a conducting wire. Which of the following graphs best represents the total net charge that has passed through the cross section since time zero?

choices.label: The figure shows the graph of a sinusoidal curve in the first and fourth quadrants of a coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled “Time,” and no values are indicated along it. The vertical axis is labeled “Charge,” and the value 0 is indicated. The curve intersects the horizontal axis at one fourth and three fourths of the way along the horizontal axis. The curve reaches maxima on the vertical axis and above the end of the horizontal axis. The curve reaches a minimum at a point halfway along the horizontal axis.

The figure shows the graph of a sinusoidal curve in the first and fourth quadrants of a coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled “Time,” and no values are indicated along it. The vertical axis is labeled “Charge,” and the value 0 is indicated. The curve intersects the horizontal axis at the origin, at a point halfway along the horizontal axis, and at the end of the horizontal axis. The curve reaches a maximum at one fourth of the way along the horizontal axis, and reaches a minimum at three fourths of the way along the horizontal axis.

The figure shows the graph of a sinusoidal curve in the first and fourth quadrants of a coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled “Time,” and no values are indicated along it. The vertical axis is labeled “Charge,” and the value 0 is indicated. The curve starts at the origin, and then decreases until it reaches a flat minimum at a point halfway along the horizontal axis and then increases back up to the horizontal axis, reaching zero at the end of the horizontal axis. The curve is tangential to the horizontal axis at the start and end points.

The figure shows the graph of a sinusoidal curve in the first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled “Time,” and no values are indicated along it. The vertical axis is labeled “Charge,” and the value 0 is indicated. The curve starts at the origin, and then increases until it reaches a flat maximum at a point halfway along the horizontal axis and then decreases back down to the horizontal axis, reaching zero at the end of the horizontal axis. The curve is tangential to the horizontal axis at the start and end points.

content.answer: The figure shows the graph of a sinusoidal curve in the first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled “Time,” and no values are indicated along it. The vertical axis is labeled “Charge,” and the value 0 is indicated. The curve starts at the origin, and then increases until it reaches a flat maximum at a point halfway along the horizontal axis and then decreases back down to the horizontal axis, reaching zero at the end of the horizontal axis. The curve is tangential to the horizontal axis at the start and end points.

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
